<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Pasta skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Pasta</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_prepared_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox prepared food (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox prepared food</a>
</p><p><b>Pasta</b> is a <a href="/wiki/Staple_food" title="Staple food">staple food</a><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> of traditional <a href="/w/index.php?title=Italian_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Italian cuisine (page does not exist)">Italian cuisine</a>, with the first reference dating to 1154 in <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">Sicily</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> It is also commonly used to refer to the variety of pasta <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dish_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dish (food) (page does not exist)">dishes</a>. Typically pasta is made from an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unleavened&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unleavened (page does not exist)">unleavened</a> <a href="/wiki/Dough" title="Dough">dough</a> of a <a href="/wiki/Durum_wheat" title="Durum wheat" class="mw-redirect">durum wheat</a> <a href="/wiki/Flour" title="Flour">flour</a> mixed with water and formed into sheets or various shapes, then <a href="/wiki/Cooking" title="Cooking">cooked</a> and served in any number of dishes. It can be made with flour from other <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">cereals</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_grain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food grain (page does not exist)">grains</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egg_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egg (food) (page does not exist)">eggs</a> may be used instead of water. Pastas may be divided into two broad categories, dried (<i>pasta secca</i>) and fresh (<i>pasta fresca</i>). Chicken eggs frequently dominate as the source of the liquid component in fresh pasta.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Most dried pasta is commercially produced via an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_extrusion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food extrusion (page does not exist)">extrusion</a> process. Fresh pasta was traditionally produced by hand, sometimes with the aid of simple machines,<sup id="cite_ref-Marcella_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marcella-3">[3]</a></sup> but today many varieties of fresh pasta are also commercially produced by large scale machines, and the products are widely available in supermarkets.
</p><p>Both dried and fresh pasta come in a number of shapes and varieties, with 310 specific forms known variably by over 1300 names having been recently documented.<sup id="cite_ref-Zanini_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zanini-4">[4]</a></sup> In Italy the names of specific pasta shapes or types often vary with locale. For example the form <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cavatelli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cavatelli (page does not exist)">cavatelli</a></i> is known by 28 different names depending on region and town. Common forms of pasta include long shapes, short shapes, tubes, flat shapes and sheets, miniature soup shapes, filled or stuffed, and specialty or decorative shapes.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a category in Italian cuisine, both dried and fresh pastas are classically used in one of three kinds of prepared dishes. As <i>pasta asciutta</i> (or pastasciutta) cooked pasta is plated and served with a complementary sauce or condiment. A second classification of pasta dishes is <i>pasta in brodo</i> in which the pasta is part of a soup-type dish. A third category is <i>pasta al forno</i> in which the pasta incorporated into a dish that is subsequently baked.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pasta is generally a simple dish, but comes in large varieties because it is a versatile food item. Some pasta dishes are served as a first course in Italy because the portion sizes are small and simple. Pasta is also prepared in light lunches, such as salads or large portion sizes for dinner. It can be prepared by hand or food processor and served hot or cold. Pasta sauces vary in taste, color and texture. When choosing which type of pasta and sauce to serve together, there is a general rule that must be observed. Simple sauces like pesto are ideal for long and thin strands of pasta while tomato sauce combines well with thicker pastas. Thicker and chunkier sauces have the better ability to cling onto the holes and cuts of short, tubular, twisted pastas. The ratio of sauce to pasta varies according to taste and texture, however traditionally the sauce should not be excessive as the pasta itself must still be tasted. The extra sauce left on the plate after all of the pasta is eaten is often mopped up with a piece of bread.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</li>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>First attested in English in 1874, the word <i>pasta</i> comes from <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a> <i>pasta</i>, in turn from <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> <i>pasta</i> "dough, pastry cake", itself the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Latinisation_(literature)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Latinisation (literature) (page does not exist)">latinisation</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> παστά (<i>pasta</i>) "barley <a href="/wiki/Porridge" title="Porridge">porridge</a>", in turn from παστός (<i>pastos</i>), "sprinkled with salt, salted".<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:6-alimenti,_pasta,Taccuino_Sanitatis,_Casanatense_4182..jpg" title="File:6-alimenti, pasta,Taccuino Sanitatis, Casanatense 4182..jpg">File:6-alimenti, pasta,Taccuino Sanitatis, Casanatense 4182..jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Making pasta; illustration from the 15<sup>th</sup> century edition of <i><a href="/wiki/Tacuinum_Sanitatis" title="Tacuinum Sanitatis">Tacuinum Sanitatis</a></i>, a Latin translation of the <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic" class="mw-redirect">Arabic</a> work <i>Taqwīm al-sihha</i> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ibn_Butlan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ibn Butlan (page does not exist)">Ibn Butlan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-11">[11]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the 1st century <a href="/wiki/Before_Christ" title="Before Christ" class="mw-redirect">BC</a> writings of <a href="/wiki/Horace" title="Horace">Horace</a>, <i>lagana</i> (Sing.: <i>laganum</i>) were fine sheets of fried dough <sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> and were an everyday foodstuff.<sup id="cite_ref-ss15_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ss15-13">[13]</a></sup> Writing in the 2nd century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Athenaeus_of_Naucratis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Athenaeus of Naucratis (page does not exist)">Athenaeus of Naucratis</a> provides a recipe for <i>lagana</i> which he attributes to the 1st century Chrysippus of Tyana: sheets of dough made of wheat flour and the juice of crushed lettuce, then flavoured with spices and deep-fried in oil.<sup id="cite_ref-ss15_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ss15-13">[13]</a></sup> An early 5<sup>th</sup> century cookbook describes a dish called <i>lagana</i> that consisted of layers of dough with meat stuffing, a possible ancestor of modern-day <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lasagna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lasagna (page does not exist)">lasagna</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ss15_13-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ss15-13">[13]</a></sup> However, the method of cooking these sheets of dough does not correspond to our modern definition of either a fresh or dry pasta product, which only had similar basic ingredients and perhaps the shape.<sup id="cite_ref-ss15_13-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ss15-13">[13]</a></sup> The first concrete information concerning pasta products in Italy dates from the 13<sup>th</sup> or 14<sup>th</sup> century.<sup id="cite_ref-Serventi_2002_10_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serventi_2002_10-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historians have noted several lexical milestones relevant to pasta, none of which changes these basic characteristics. For example, the works of the 2nd century AD Greek physician <a href="/wiki/Galen" title="Galen">Galen</a> mention <i>itrion</i>, homogeneous compounds made up of flour and water.<sup id="cite_ref-ss17_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ss17-15">[15]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Talmud" title="Jerusalem Talmud">Jerusalem Talmud</a> records that <i>itrium</i>, a kind of boiled dough,<sup id="cite_ref-ss17_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ss17-15">[15]</a></sup> was common in <a href="/wiki/Palestine" title="Palestine">Palestine</a> from the 3<sup>rd</sup> to 5<sup>th</sup> centuries AD,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> A dictionary compiled by the 9<sup>th</sup> century Arab physician and lexicographer Isho bar Ali<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> defines <i>itriyya</i>, the Arabic cognate, as string-like shapes made of semolina and dried before cooking. The geographical text of <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_al-Idrisi" title="Muhammad al-Idrisi">Muhammad al-Idrisi</a>, compiled for the Norman King of Sicily <a href="/wiki/Roger_II_of_Sicily" title="Roger II of Sicily">Roger II</a> in 1154 mentions <i>itriyya</i> manufactured and exported from Norman Sicily:
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">"West of Termini there is a delightful settlement called Trabia.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Its ever-flowing streams propel a number of mills. Here there are huge buildings in the countryside where they make vast quantities of <i>itriyya</i> which is exported everywhere: to <a href="/wiki/Calabria" title="Calabria">Calabria</a>, to Muslim and Christian countries. Very many shiploads are sent."<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<p><i>Itriyya</i> gives rise to <i>trie</i> in Italian,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} signifying long strips such as <i>tagliatelle</i> and <i>trenette</i>. One form of <i>itriyya</i> with a long history is <i>laganum</i> (plural <i>lagana</i>), which in Latin refers to a thin sheet of dough,<sup id="cite_ref-ss15_13-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ss15-13">[13]</a></sup> and gives rise to Italian <i>lasagna</i>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Moser_Spaghetti_essender_Junge.jpg" title="File:Moser Spaghetti essender Junge.jpg">File:Moser Spaghetti essender Junge.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Boy with Spaghetti</i> by Julius Moser, c. 1808.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Napoli_-_Negozio_di_prodotti_tipici_Campani.jpg" title="File:Napoli - Negozio di prodotti tipici Campani.jpg">File:Napoli - Negozio di prodotti tipici Campani.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Typical products shop in <a href="/wiki/Naples" title="Naples">Naples</a> with pasta on display</i></div></div></div>
<p>According to historians like Charles Perry, the Arabs adapted noodles for long journeys in the 5<sup>th</sup> century, the first written record of dry pasta.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The dried pasta introduced was being produced in great quantities in Palermo at that time.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>In North Africa, a food similar to pasta, known as <a href="/wiki/Couscous" title="Couscous">couscous</a>, has been eaten for centuries. However, it lacks the distinguishing malleable nature of pasta, couscous being more akin to droplets of dough. At first, dry pasta was a luxury item in Italy because of high labor costs; durum wheat semolina had to be kneaded for a long time.
</p><p>There is a legend of <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo" title="Marco Polo">Marco Polo</a> importing pasta from China<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> which originated with the <i>Macaroni Journal</i>, published by an association of food industries with the goal of promoting the use of pasta in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rustichello_da_Pisa" title="Rustichello da Pisa">Rustichello da Pisa</a> writes in his <i><a href="/wiki/The_Travels_of_Marco_Polo" title="The Travels of Marco Polo">Travels</a></i> that Marco Polo described a food similar to "lagana". <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jeffrey_Steingarten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jeffrey Steingarten (page does not exist)">Jeffrey Steingarten</a> asserts that <a href="/wiki/Arab_people" title="Arab people">Arabs</a> introduced pasta in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emirate_of_Sicily&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emirate of Sicily (page does not exist)">Emirate of Sicily</a> in the ninth century, mentioning also that traces of pasta have been found in ancient Greece and that <a href="/wiki/Jane_Grigson" title="Jane Grigson">Jane Grigson</a> believed the Marco Polo story to have originated in the 1920s or 30s in an advertisement for a Canadian Spaghetti company.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 14<sup>th</sup> and 15<sup>th</sup> centuries, dried pasta became popular for its easy storage. This allowed people to store dried pasta in ships when exploring the New World.<sup id="cite_ref-Diana_Viola_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diana_Viola-23">[23]</a></sup> A century later, pasta was present around the globe during the voyages of discovery.<sup id="cite_ref-Demetri_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Demetri-24">[24]</a></sup> The invention of the first tomato sauces dates back from the late 18<sup>th</sup> century: the first written record of pasta with tomato sauce can be found in the 1790 cookbook <i>L'Apicio Moderno</i> by <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Roman</a> <a href="/wiki/Chef" title="Chef">chef</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Francesco_Leonardi_(Chef)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Francesco Leonardi (Chef) (page does not exist)">Francesco Leonardi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> Before tomato sauce was introduced, pasta was eaten dry with the fingers; the liquid sauce demanded the use of a fork.<sup id="cite_ref-Diana_Viola_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Diana_Viola-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="History_of_manufacturing">History of manufacturing</span></h3>
<p>Pasta manufacturing machines were made since the 1600s across the coast of <a href="/wiki/Sanremo" title="Sanremo">Sanremo</a>. The extrusion press produced large amounts of uniform pastas. The consistency of shapes and texture of the pasta manufactured by the extrusion press is believed to be superior to hand made pasta. This technology has spread to other areas including <a href="/wiki/Genoa" title="Genoa">Genoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apulia" title="Apulia">Apulia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brindisi" title="Brindisi">Brindisi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bari" title="Bari">Bari</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tuscany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tuscany (page does not exist)">Tuscany</a>. By 1867, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buitoni&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buitoni (page does not exist)">Buitoni</a> Company in upper <a href="/wiki/Tiber" title="Tiber">Tiber</a> Valley became one of the most successful and well-known pasta manufacturers in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution">Evolution</span></h2>
<p>It is to be noted that the idea of using tomato sauce to give pasta its flavour was revolutionary since it was originally eaten plain. It was eaten with the hands as only the wealthy could afford eating utensils. The consumption of pasta has changed over time; it was once a small, simple item, but it is now often eaten in much larger portions and as part of complex, sophisticated dishes. Factors such as low prices and ease of cooking contribute to the growing popularity of this staple item.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_modern_times">In modern times</span></h3>
<p>The art of pasta making and the devotion to the food as a whole has evolved since pasta was first conceptualized. “It is estimated that Italians eat over sixty pounds of pasta per person, per year, easily beating Americans, who eat about twenty pounds per person.”<sup id="cite_ref-lifeinitaly.com_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lifeinitaly.com-28">[28]</a></sup> Pasta is so beloved in the nation of Italy that individual consumption exceeds the average production of wheat of the country; thus Italy frequently imports wheat for pasta making. In contemporary society pasta is ubiquitous, and individuals can find a variety of types in local supermarkets. With the worldwide demand for this staple food, pasta is now largely mass-produced in factories and only a tiny proportion is crafted by hand. However, while pasta is made everywhere, “the product from Italy keeps to time-tested production methods that create a superior pasta”.<sup id="cite_ref-lifeinitaly.com_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lifeinitaly.com-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pasta was originally solely a part of Italian and European cuisine owing to its popularity there. With an increase in popularity on a world-wide scale, pasta has crossed international borders and is now a popular form of fast food and a staple in North America and elsewhere. This is due to the great amount of Italian immigration into Canada and the United States around the beginning of the 20<sup>th</sup> century. Similarly an immense immigration of Italians into South Africa ensured that spaghetti and meatballs became an essential part of South African cuisine.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ingredients">Ingredients</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lasagna.jpg" title="File:Lasagna.jpg">File:Lasagna.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Lasagne" title="Lasagne">Lasagne</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since the time of Cato, basic pasta dough has been made mostly of wheat flour or <a href="/wiki/Semolina" title="Semolina">semolina</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Zanini_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zanini-4">[4]</a></sup> with durum wheat used predominantely in the South of Italy and soft wheat in the North. Regionally other grains have been used, including those from barley, buckwheat, rye, rice, and maize, as well as chestnut and chickpea flours. In modern times to meet the demands of both health conscious and <a href="/wiki/Coeliac_disease" title="Coeliac disease">coeliac sufferers</a> the use of rice, maize and whole durum wheat has become commercially significant. Grain flours may also be supplemented with cooked potatoes.
</p><p>Beyond hens' eggs and water, liquids have included duck eggs, milk or cream, olive or walnut oil, wine, ink from octopus, squid or cuttlefish, and even pigs' blood. Other additions to the basic flour-liquid mixture may include vegetables purees such as spinach or tomato, mushrooms, cheeses, herbs, spices and other seasonings. While pastas are, most typically, made from unleavened doughs, the use of yeast-raised doughs are also known for at least nine different pasta forms.<sup id="cite_ref-Zanini_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zanini-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Varieties">Varieties</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Pasta 2006 1.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Long pasta
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Pasta 2006 2.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Short pasta
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Pasta 2006 3.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Short pasta
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Pasta 2006 4.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Minute pasta (<i>pastina</i>, used for soups)
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Pasta 2006 5.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><i>Pasta all'uovo</i> (egg pasta)
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Pasta 2006 6.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Fresh pasta
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px"><div style="width: 155px">
			<div class="thumb" style="height: 150px;">Pasta 2006 7.jpg</div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Pasta for <i>pasta al forno</i> (baked pasta) dishes
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fresh">Fresh</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cannelloni_mit_Hackfleischf%C3%BCllung.jpg" title="File:Cannelloni mit Hackfleischfüllung.jpg">File:Cannelloni mit Hackfleischfüllung.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Cannelloni, a cylindrical type of pasta generally served baked with a filling and covered by a sauce.</div></div></div>
<p>Fresh pasta is usually locally made with fresh ingredients unless it is destined to be shipped, in which case consideration is given to the spoilage rates of the desired ingredients such as eggs or herbs. Furthermore, fresh pasta is usually made with a mixture of eggs and all-purpose flour or “00” low gluten flour. Since it contains eggs, it is more tender compared to dried pasta and only takes about half the time to cook.<sup id="cite_ref-Quessenberry_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Quessenberry-30">[30]</a></sup> Delicate sauces are preferred for fresh pasta in order to let the pasta take front stage.<sup id="cite_ref-Christensen_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christensen-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Fresh pastas do not expand in size after cooking; therefore, one and a half pounds of pasta are needed to serve 4 people generously.<sup id="cite_ref-Quessenberry_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Quessenberry-30">[30]</a></sup> Fresh egg pasta is generally cut into strands of various widths and thicknesses depending on which pasta is to be made (e.g. fettuccine, pappardelle, and lasagne). It is best served with meat, cheese, or vegetables to create <a href="/wiki/Ravioli" title="Ravioli">ravioli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tortellini" title="Tortellini">tortellini</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cannelloni" title="Cannelloni">cannelloni</a>. Fresh egg pasta is well known in the <a href="/wiki/Piedmont" title="Piedmont">Piedmont</a> area near the border of France. In this area, dough is only made out of egg yolk and flour resulting in a very refined flavour and texture. This pasta is often served simply with butter sauce and thinly sliced truffles that are native to this region. In other areas, such as <a href="/wiki/Apulia" title="Apulia">Apulia</a> fresh pasta can be made without eggs. The only ingredients needed to make the pasta dough is semolina flour and water, which is often shaped into <a href="/w/index.php?title=Orecchiette&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Orecchiette (page does not exist)">orecchiette</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cavatelli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cavatelli (page does not exist)">cavatelli</a>. Fresh pasta for cavatelli is also popular in other places including <a href="/wiki/Sicily" title="Sicily">Sicily</a>. However, the dough is prepared differently: it is made of flour and <a href="/wiki/Ricotta" title="Ricotta">ricotta</a> cheese instead.<sup id="cite_ref-Laux_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Laux-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dried">Dried</span></h3>
<p>Dried pasta can also be defined as factory-made pasta because it is usually produced in large amounts that require large machines with superior processing capabilities to manufacture.<sup id="cite_ref-Laux_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Laux-32">[32]</a></sup> Dried pasta is mainly shipped over to farther locations and has a longer shelf life. The ingredients required to make dried pasta include semolina flour and water. Eggs can be added for flavour and richness, but are not needed to make dried pasta. In contrast to fresh pasta, dried pasta needs to be dried at a low temperature for several days to evaporate all the moisture allowing it to be stored for a longer period. Dried pastas are best served in hearty dishes like <a href="/wiki/Rag%C3%B9" title="Ragù">ragu</a> sauces, soups, and casseroles.<sup id="cite_ref-Christensen_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christensen-31">[31]</a></sup> Once it is cooked, the dried pasta will usually increase in size by double of its original proportion. Therefore, approximately one pound of dried pasta serves up to four people.<sup id="cite_ref-Quessenberry_30-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Quessenberry-30">[30]</a></sup> The way to create the finest dried pasta is by mixing golden semolina flour, ground from durum wheat, with water. Good quality dried pasta is identified by its slight rough surface and compact body that helps maintain its firmness in cooking, since it swells considerably in size when cooked.<sup id="cite_ref-Laux_32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Laux-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culinary_uses">Culinary uses</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pasta_with_pesto.jpg" title="File:Pasta with pesto.jpg">File:Pasta with pesto.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Pesto <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cavatappi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cavatappi (page does not exist)">Cavatappi</a></i>.</div></div></div>
<p>Pasta is generally served with some type of sauce; the sauce and the type of pasta are usually matched based on consistency and ease of eating. Northern Italian cooking uses less tomato sauce, garlic and herbs. In Northern Italy <i><a href="/wiki/White_sauce" title="White sauce" class="mw-redirect">white sauce</a></i> is more common.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> However Italian cuisine is best identified by individual regions. Pasta dishes with lighter use of tomato are found in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trentino-Alto_Adige&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trentino-Alto Adige (page does not exist)">Trentino-Alto Adige</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emilia_Romagna" title="Emilia Romagna" class="mw-redirect">Emilia Romagna</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> In Bologna, the meat-based <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bolognese_sauce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bolognese sauce (page does not exist)">Bolognese sauce</a></i> incorporates a small amount of tomato concentrate and a green sauce called <i><a href="/wiki/Pesto" title="Pesto">pesto</a></i> originates from Genoa. In <a href="/wiki/Central_Italy" title="Central Italy">Central Italy</a>, there are sauces such as <i><a href="/wiki/Tomato_sauce" title="Tomato sauce">tomato sauce</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Amatriciana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amatriciana (page does not exist)">amatriciana</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arrabbiata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arrabbiata (page does not exist)">arrabbiata</a></i> and the egg-based <i><a href="/wiki/Carbonara" title="Carbonara">carbonara</a></i>. In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tuscany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tuscany (page does not exist)">Tuscany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Umbria" title="Umbria">Umbria</a> pasta is often served <i>alla carrettiera</i> (a tomato sauce spiked with peperoncini hot peppers).<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>Tomato sauces are also present in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Italy" title="Southern Italy">Southern Italian</a> cuisine, where they originated. In Southern Italy more complex variations include pasta paired with fresh vegetables, olives, capers or seafood. Varieties include <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Puttanesca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Puttanesca (page does not exist)">puttanesca</a></i>, <i>pasta alla norma</i> (tomatoes, eggplant and fresh or baked cheese), <i>pasta con le sarde</i> (fresh sardines, pine nuts, fennel and olive oil), <i>spaghetti aglio, olio e peperoncino</i> (literally with garlic, [olive] oil and hot chili peppers).
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Production">Production</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Howto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Howto (page does not exist)">Template:Howto</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Homemade">Homemade</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pasta_machine_2.jpg" title="File:Pasta machine 2.jpg">File:Pasta machine 2.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A pasta machine in use.</div></div></div>
<p>Ingredients to make pasta dough include semolina flour, egg, salt and water. Flour is first mounded on a flat surface and then a well in the pile of flour is created. Egg is then poured into the well and a fork is used to mix the egg and flour. Salt is added to the dough and is kneaded until it is smooth and dry.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Dubious |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} If the dough remains sticky, semolina flour is further added and is kneaded until it is dry. The dough is then shaped into pieces that are needed to make sheets of pasta.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> Then a rolling pin is used to flatten the dough. There are a variety of ways to shape the sheets of pasta depending on the type of pasta that needs to be made. The most popular types include <a href="/wiki/Penne" title="Penne">penne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spaghetti" title="Spaghetti">spaghetti</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Macaroni" title="Macaroni">macaroni</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kitchen pasta <a href="/wiki/Machine" title="Machine">machines</a>, also called pasta makers, are popular with cooks who make large amounts of homemade pasta. Sheets of pasta dough are fed into the machine by hand, and by turning a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hand_crank&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hand crank (page does not exist)">hand crank</a>, the pasta is then <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_extrusion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food extrusion (page does not exist)">extruded</a> through a machine 'comb' that shapes the pasta noodles as they are extruded.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Storage">Storage</span></h3>
<p>The storage of pasta depends on how far along it is processed. Uncooked pasta is kept dry and can sit in the cupboard for a year. The pasta must be airtight and stored in a dry area. Make sure it is kept in a cool place. Cooked pasta is stored in the refrigerator for a maximum of five days in an airtight container. Adding a couple teaspoons of oil helps keep the food from sticking to each other and the container. If the cooked pasta is not used in the five days it may be frozen for up to two or three months. The pasta will start to dry after a period of time, but it varies with the type of pasta. Should the pasta be dried completely, place it back into the cupboard.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Factory-manufactured">Factory-manufactured</span></h3>
<p>The ingredients to make dried pasta usually include water, semolina flour, egg for colour and richness, vegetable juice (such as spinach, beet, tomato, carrot) for colour and taste, and herbs or spices for flavour; however, ingredients may vary. Semolina flour is piled in silos that will transfer the semolina through a pipe and into a mixing machine. Warm water is poured into the machine to mix with the semolina flour. The machine kneads it until the mixture becomes firm and dry. If pasta is to be flavoured, eggs, vegetable juices, and herbs are added to the mixture. The dough is then passed into the laminator to be flattened into sheets. It is then further compressed by the vacuum mixer-machine to clear out air bubbles and excess water from the dough until the moisture content is reduced to 12%. Next, the dough is processed in the steamer to kill any existing bacteria it may contain.
</p><p>After steaming, the dough is ready to be cut. Depending on the type of pasta to be made, the dough can either be cut or extruded through dies. Then the pasta is set in a drying tank so that it can be dried under specific conditions of heat, moisture, and time depending on the type of pasta that is being dried. The final step is to package the pasta properly. Fresh pasta is sealed in a clear, airtight plastic container. During the sealing process air is sucked out of the container and replaced with carbon dioxide and nitrogen mixture. This slows microbial growth and prolongs its shelf life. Dried pastas are packaged differently than fresh pasta. It is placed in stainless steel buckets that are transferred to appropriate packaging stations to be portioned and sealed in plastic or cardboard packages.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Market">Market</span></h2>
<p>Italy produced 1,432,990 tons of spaghetti in 1955, of which 74,000 tons was <a href="/wiki/Export" title="Export">exported</a>, and had a production capacity of 3 million tons.<sup id="cite_ref-1955cons_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1955cons-42">[42]</a></sup> By 2011, the three largest producers of dried pasta were Italy (3,247,322 tonnes), the United States (3,000,000 tonnes), and Brazil (1,300,000 tonnes).<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> The largest per capita consumers of pasta in 2011 were Italy (26.0&#160;kg/person), Venezuela (12.0&#160;kg/person), Tunisia (11.7&#160;kg/person), and Greece (10.4&#160;kg/person).
</p><p>In the European Union, total pasta sales in 2008 were US $8.361 billion, of which $5.722 billion was for dried pasta, $2.244 billion was for fresh or chilled pasta, and $395 million was for canned or preserved pasta.<sup id="cite_ref-AAFC_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAFC-44">[44]</a></sup> In 2009, retail sales of pasta represented a $2.809 billion market in Italy, $1.402 billion in Germany, and $1.179 billion in France.<sup id="cite_ref-AAFC_44-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAFC-44">[44]</a></sup> Fresh pasta represented a $996 million market in Italy in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-AAFC_44-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAFC-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>Italy is the world's largest exporter of pasta; in 2007, it exported 1.7 million tons of pasta, and the largest export markets were Germany (20.4%), France (13.7%), the United Kingdom (12.6%), the United States (9.5%), and Japan (4.25%). Italy's pasta exports represented 53% of its total production in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-italy2007_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-italy2007-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition">Nutrition</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Primary_sources&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Primary sources (page does not exist)">Template:Primary sources</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rotini_Yellow_Red_Green.jpg" title="File:Rotini Yellow Red Green.jpg">File:Rotini Yellow Red Green.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Three different colours of rotini.</div></div></div>
<p>Pasta, especially whole wheat pasta, is known to have several health benefits. Whole wheat contains considerable amounts of minerals such as magnesium, iron, calcium, potassium, zinc, selenium and manganese.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Minerals are important for the body because they help with the structure of bones, regulate heart beat, maintain muscle, and take part in regulating cell growth.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pasta contains complex <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a>, which release energy slowly compared to sugar, providing energy for a longer time. Pasta also contains a small amount of sodium, and has no <a href="/wiki/Cholesterol" title="Cholesterol">cholesterol</a>. Assorted pastas are rich in essential nutrients such as iron and vitamin B.<sup id="cite_ref-Pasta_Nutrition_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pasta_Nutrition-48">[48]</a></sup> Another benefit of eating pasta is that it provides <a href="/wiki/Niacin" title="Niacin">niacin</a> (Vitamin B<sub>3</sub>). This vitamin is essential for bodily functions such as converting carbohydrates into <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a>, which produces energy for the body. Enriched pasta also contains folic acid, which is beneficial for child-bearing women. <a href="/wiki/Folic_acid" title="Folic acid">Folic acid</a> is needed for the proper growth of cells and development of the embryo.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> Pasta may not contribute to obesity, as weight gain is often caused by excess calories in a diet, rather than its carbohydrate content.<sup id="cite_ref-foodnutritionscience.com_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foodnutritionscience.com-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>The amount of protein in pasta depends on the type of flour used to manufacture it. If it is made from durum wheat, the pasta contains protein and <a href="/wiki/Gluten" title="Gluten">gluten</a>. Pasta is considered to be a good source of nutrition for vegetarians<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:By_whom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:By whom (page does not exist)">Template:By whom</a> because it contains protein comprising six of the nine essential <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">amino acids</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">Mediterranean diet</a> is a health approach in which the goal is to prevent illness and diseases. This diet is composed mainly of a number of plant foods such as pasta. Other foods include olive oil, dairy products, eggs, red meats, and small amounts of fish and poultry.<sup id="cite_ref-foodnutritionscience.com_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foodnutritionscience.com-50">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_adaptations">International adaptations</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Asian_Style_Italian_Pasta.jpg" title="File:Asian Style Italian Pasta.jpg">File:Asian Style Italian Pasta.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An Asian-style "Italian" pasta</div></div></div>
<p>As pasta was introduced elsewhere in the world, it became incorporated into a number of local cuisines, which often have significantly different ways of preparation from those of Italy. In <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, the local Chinese have adopted pasta, primarily <a href="/wiki/Spaghetti" title="Spaghetti">spaghetti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macaroni" title="Macaroni">macaroni</a>, as an ingredient in the <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong-style_Western_cuisine" title="Hong Kong-style Western cuisine" class="mw-redirect">Hong Kong-style Western cuisine</a>.
</p><p>When pasta was introduced to several nations, every culture adopted different style of preparing it. In the past, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Roman" title="Ancient Roman" class="mw-redirect">ancient Romans</a> cooked pastas by frying or boiling it. It was also sweetened with honey or tossed with <a href="/wiki/Garum" title="Garum">garum</a>. Ancient Romans also enjoyed baking it in rich pies, called timballi.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Cha_chaan_teng" title="Cha chaan teng">Cha chaan teng</a> (茶餐廳), macaroni is cooked in water and served in broth with <a href="/wiki/Ham" title="Ham">ham</a> or <a href="/wiki/Sausage" title="Sausage">frankfurter sausages</a>, peas, <a href="/wiki/Shiitake" title="Shiitake">black mushrooms</a>, and optionally <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egg_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egg (food) (page does not exist)">eggs</a>, reminiscent of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Noodle_soup&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Noodle soup (page does not exist)">noodle soup</a> dishes. This is often a course for breakfast or light lunch fare.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> These affordable dining shops evolved from American food rations after World War II due to lack of supplies, and they continue to be popular for people with modest means.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cheese_pepper_pasta.JPG" title="File:Cheese pepper pasta.JPG">File:Cheese pepper pasta.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A home-made cheese pepper <i>Nepalese</i> pasta (macaroni)</div></div></div>
<p>Two common spaghetti dishes served in <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rag%C3%B9_alla_bolognese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ragù alla bolognese (page does not exist)">Bolognese</a> (ミートソース) and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Naporitan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Naporitan (page does not exist)">Napolitan</a> (ナポリタン). In <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, macaroni has been adopted and cooked in an Nepalese way. Boiled macaroni is sautéed along with <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">turmeric</a>, finely chopped green chillies, onions and cabbage. In <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> hilopittes is considered one of the finest types of dried egg pasta. It is cooked either in tomato sauce or with various kinds of casserole meat. It is usually served with Greek cheese of any type.
In <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> too,macaroni is prepared in same way but in Indianized way.
</p><p>Pasta is also widespread in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">Southern Cone</a>, as well most of the rest of <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, mostly pervasive in the areas with mild to strong <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italian</a> roots, such as Central Argentina, and the eight southernmost Brazilian states (where <a href="/wiki/Macaroni" title="Macaroni">macaroni</a> are called <i>macarrão</i>, and more general pasta is under the umbrella term <i>massa</i>, literally "dough", together with some <a href="/wiki/Japanese_noodles" title="Japanese noodles">Japanese noodles</a>, such as <i>bifum</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_vermicelli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice vermicelli (page does not exist)">rice vermicelli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yakisoba" title="Yakisoba">yakisoba</a>, which also entered general taste). The local names for the pasta are many times varieties of the Italian names, such as ñoquis/nhoque for gnocchi, ravioles/ravióli for ravioli, or tallarines/talharim for tagliatelle, although some of the most popular pasta in Brazil, such as the <i>parafuso</i> ("screw", "bolt"), a specialty of the country's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pasta_salad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pasta salad (page does not exist)">pasta salads</a>, are also way different both in name and format from its closest Italian relatives, in this case the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fusilli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fusilli (page does not exist)">fusilli</a> ("rifle").<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweden (page does not exist)">Sweden</a>, spaghetti is traditionally served with <i>köttfärssås</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Bolognese_sauce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bolognese sauce (page does not exist)">Bolognese sauce</a>), which is minced meat in a thick tomato soup.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, spaghetti is often served with a distinct, slightly sweet yet flavourful meat sauce (the base of which would be tomato sauce or paste and ketchup), frequently containing ground beef or pork and diced hot dogs and ham. It is spiced with some soy sauce, heavy quantities of garlic, dried oregano sprigs and sometimes with dried bay leaf, and afterwards topped with grated cheese. Other pasta dishes are also cooked nowadays in the Filipino kitchen, like carbonara, pasta with alfredo sauce, and baked macaroni. These dishes are usually cooked for gatherings and special occasions, like family reunions or Christmas. Macaroni or other tube pasta is also used in <i>sopas</i>, a local chicken broth soup.
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fettuccine_alfredo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fettuccine alfredo (page does not exist)">Fettuccine alfredo</a></i> with cream, cheese and butter, and spaghetti with tomato sauce (with or without meat) are popular Italian-style dishes in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>.
</p><p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a>, boscaiola sauce, based on bacon and mushrooms, is one favorite among many.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Regulations">Regulations</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Italy">Italy</span></h3>
<p>Although numerous variations of ingredients for different pasta products are known, in Italy the commercial manufacturing and labeling of pasta for sale as a food product within the country is highly regulated.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> Italian regulations recognise three categories of commercially manufactured dried pasta as well as manufactured fresh and stabilized pasta:
</p><p><b>Pasta</b>: Dried pasta with three subcategories – (i.) Durum wheat semolina pasta (<i>pasta di semola di grano duro</i>), (ii.) Low grade durum wheat semolina pasta (<i>pasta di semolato di grano duro</i>) and (iii.) Durum wheat whole meal pasta (<i>pasta di semola integrale di grano duro</i>). Pastas made under this category must be made only with durum wheat semolina or durum wheat whole-meal semolina and water, with an allowance for up to 3% of soft-wheat flour as part of the durum flour. Dried pastas made under this category must be labeled according to the subcategory.
</p><p><b>Special pastas</b> (<i>paste speciali</i>): As Pasta above, with additional ingredients other than flour and water or eggs. Special pastas must be labeled as durum wheat semolina pasta on the packaging completed by mentioning the added ingredients used (e.g., spinach). The 3% soft flour limitation still applies.
</p><p><b>Egg pasta</b> (<i>pasta all'uovo</i>): May only be manufactured using durum wheat semolina with at least 4 hens’ eggs (chicken) weighing at least 200&#160;grams (without the shells) per kilogram of semolina, or a liquid egg product produced only with hen’s eggs. Pasta made and sold in Italy under this category must be labeled egg pasta.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pasta_Machine.jpg" title="File:Pasta Machine.jpg">File:Pasta Machine.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A small hand-cranked pasta machine designed to sheet fresh pasta dough and cut <a href="/wiki/Tagliatelle" title="Tagliatelle">tagliatelle</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><b>Fresh and stabilized pastas</b> (<i>paste alimentari fresche e stabilizzate</i>): Includes fresh and stabilized pastas, which may be made with soft-wheat flour without restriction on the amount. Prepackaged fresh pasta must have a water content not less than 24%, must be stored refrigerated at a temperature of not more than 4 °C (with a 2°C tolerance), must have undergone a heat treatment at least equivalent to pasteurisation, and must be sold within 5 days of the date of manufacture. Stabilized pasta has a lower allowed water content of 20%, and is manufactured using a process and heat treatment that allows it to be transported and stored at ambient temperatures.
</p><p>The Italian regulations under Presidential Decree N° 187 apply only to the commercial manufacturing of pastas both made and sold within Italy. They are not applicable either to pasta made for export from Italy or to pastas imported into Italy from other countries. They also do not apply to pastas made in restaurants.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="U.S.">U.S.</span></h3>
<p>In the U.S., regulations for commercial pasta products occur both at the Federal and State levels.
At the Federal level, consistent with Section 341 of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Food,_Drug,_and_Cosmetic_Act" title="Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act">Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration" title="Food and Drug Administration">Food and Drug Administration</a> (FDA) has defined <a href="/w/index.php?title=Standards_of_identity_for_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Standards of identity for food (page does not exist)">standards of identity</a> for what are broadly termed macaroni products. These standards appear in 21 CFR Part 139.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> In those regulations the requirements for standardized macaroni products of 15 specific types of dried pastas are detailed, including ingredients and product specific labeling for conforming products sold in the U.S., including imports:
</p><p><b>Macaroni products</b> – is defined as the class of food prepared by drying formed units of dough made from semolina, durum flour, farina, flour, or any combination of those ingredients with water. Within this category various optional ingredients may also be used within specified ranges, including egg white, frozen egg white or dried egg white alone or in any combination; disodium phosphate; onions, celery, garlic or bay leaf, alone or in any combination; salt; gum gluten; and concentrated glyceryl monostearate. Specific dimensions are given for the shapes named macaroni, spaghetti and vermicelli.
</p><p><b>Enriched macaroni products</b> – is largely the same as <i>macaroni products</i> except that each such food must contain of thiamin, riboflavin, niacin or niacinamide, folic acid and iron, with specified limits. Additional optional ingredients that may be added include vitamin D, calcium, and defatted wheat germ. The optional ingredients specified may be supplied through the use of dried yeast, dried torula yeast, partly defatted wheat germ, enriched farina, or enriched flour.
</p><p><b>Enriched macaroni products with fortified protein</b>–similar to <i>enriched macaroni products</i> with the addition of other ingredients to meet specific protein requirements. Edible protein sources that may be used include food grade flours or meals from nonwheat cereals or oilseeds. Products in this category must include specified amounts of thiamin, riboflavin, niacin or niacinamide and iron, but not folic acid. The products in this category may also optionally contain up to 625 milligrams of calcium.
</p><p><b>Milk macaroni products</b> – the same as <i>macaroni products</i> except that milk or a specified milk product is used as the sole moistening ingredient in preparing the dough. Other than milk, allowed milk products include concentrated milk, evaporated milk, dried milk, and a mixture of butter with skim, concentrated skim, evaporated skim, or nonfat dry milk, in any combination, with the limitation on the amount of milk solids relative to amount of milk fat.
</p><p><b>Nonfat milk macaroni products</b> – the same as <i>macaroni products</i> except that nonfat dry milk or concentrated skim milk is used in preparing the dough. The finished macaroni product must contain between 12% and 25% milk solids-not-fat. Carageenan or carageenan salts may be added in specified amounts. The use of egg whites, disodium phosphate and gum gluten optionally allowed for <i>macaroni products</i> is not permitted for this category.
</p><p><b>Enriched nonfat milk macaroni products</b> – similar to <i>nonfat milk macaroni products</i> with added requirements that products in this category contain thiamin, riboflavin, niacin or niacinamide, folic acid and iron, all within specified ranges.
</p><p><b>Vegetable macaroni products</b> – begins as <i>macaroni products</i> except that tomato (of any red variety), artichoke, beet, carrot, parsley or spinach is added in a quantity such that the solids of the added component are at least 3% by weight of the finished macaroni product. The vegetable additions may be in the form of fresh, canned, dried or a puree or paste. The addition of either the various forms of egg whites or disodium phosphate allowed for <i>macaroni products</i> is not permitted in this category.
</p><p><b>Enriched vegetable macaroni products</b> – the same as <i>vegetable macaroni products</i> with the added requirement for nutrient content specified for <i>enriched macaroni products</i>.
</p><p><b>Whole wheat macaroni products</b> – similar to <i>macaroni products</i> except that only whole wheat flour or whole wheat durum flour, or both, may be used as the wheat ingredient. Further the addition of the various forms of egg whites, disodium phosphate and gum gluten are not permitted.
</p><p><b>Wheat and soy macaroni products</b> – begins as <i>macaroni products</i> with the addition of at least 12.5% of soy flour as a fraction of the total soy and wheat flour used. The addition the various forms of egg whites and disodium phosphate are not permitted. Gum gluten may be added with a limitation that the total protein content derived from the combination of the flours and added gluten not exceed 13%.
</p><p><b>Noodle products</b> – are the class of food that is prepared by drying units of dough made from semolina, durum flour, farina, flour, alone or in any combination with liquid eggs, frozen eggs, dried eggs, egg yolks, frozen yolks, dried yolks, alone or in any combination, with or without water. Optional ingredients that may be added in allowed amounts are onions, celery, garlic, and bay leaf; salt; gum gluten; and concentrated glyceryl monostearate.
</p><p><b>Enriched noodle products</b> – similar to <i>noodle products</i> with the addition of specific requirements for amounts of thiamin, riboflavin, niacin or niacinamide, folic acid and iron, each within specified ranges. Additionally products in this category may optionally contain added vitamin D, calcium or defatted wheat germ, each within specified limits.
</p><p><b>Vegetable noodle products</b> – the same as <i>noodle products</i> with the addition of tomato (of any red variety), artichoke, beet, carrot, parsley, or spinach in an amount that is at least 3% of the finished product weight. The vegetable component may be added as fresh, canned, dried, or in the form of a puree or paste.
</p><p><b>Enriched vegetable noodle products</b> – the same as <i>vegetable noodle products</i> excluding carrot, with the specified nutrient requirements for <i>enriched noodle products</i>.
</p><p><b>Wheat and soy noodle products</b> – similar to <i>noodle products</i> except that soy flour is added in a quantity not less than 12.5% of the combined weight of the wheat and soy ingredients.
</p><p>It is important to note that the federal regulations under 21 CFR Part 139 are standards for the products noted, not mandates. Following the FDA’s standards, a number of states have, at various times, enacted their own statutes that serve as mandates for various forms of macaroni and noodle products that may be produced or sold within their borders. Many of these specifically require that the products sold within those states be of the enriched form.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> According to a report released by the Connecticut Office of Legislative Research, when Connecticut’s law was adopted in 1972 that mandated certain grain products, including macaroni products, sold within the state to be enriched it joined 38 to 40 other states in adopting the federal standards as mandates.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beyond the FDA’s standards and state statutes the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">United States Department of Agriculture</a> (USDA), which regulates federal school nutrition programs,<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> broadly requires grain and bread products served under these programs either be enriched or whole grain (see 7 CFR 210.10 (k)(5)). This includes macaroni and noodle products that are served as part the category grains/breads requirements within those programs. The USDA also allows that enriched macaroni products fortified with protein may be used and counted to meet either a gains/breads or meat/alternative meat requirement, but not as both components within the same meal.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
